The Catechism of the Catholic Church (CCC) does not specifically mention alcohol in relation to the gifts of the Holy Spirit. However, the CCC does provide guidance on the use of alcohol in general. It teaches that alcohol can be used in moderation as a gift from God, but excessive drinking is to be avoided as it can lead to harm, both physically and spiritually.

Regarding the gifts of the Holy Spirit, the Bible teaches that they are given to believers by the Holy Spirit for the common good (1 Corinthians 12:7). The Bible also teaches that individuals should not be drunk with wine, but should be filled with the Holy Spirit (Ephesians 5:18). This passage is often interpreted as a call for Christians to prioritize the gifts of the Holy Spirit over the use of alcohol.

However, there is no specific biblical or Catholic teaching that requires individuals to abstain from alcohol in order to receive or manifest the gifts of the Holy Spirit. The focus is on cultivating a virtuous and prayerful life that is open to the Holy Spirit, rather than on specific lifestyle choices such as abstaining from alcohol.
